t: Proverbs 21
The*pn king’s heart is*i in the hand of the Lord,*s Like*ild the rivers of water; He*ld turns it wherever He wishes.
Every*ln way of a man is*i right in his own eyes, But*ld the Lord*s weighs the hearts.
To*ln do righteousness and justice Is*ild more acceptable to the Lord*s than sacrifice.
A*ln haughty look, a proud heart, And*ild the plowing of the wicked are*i sin.
The*ln plans of the diligent lead*i surely to plenty, But*ld those*i of*i everyone who*i is*i hasty, surely to poverty.
Getting*ln treasures by a lying tongue Is*ild the fleeting fantasy of those who seek death.
The*ln violence of the wicked will destroy them, Because*ld they refuse to do justice.
The*ln way of a guilty man is*i perverse; But*ld as*i for*i the pure, his work is*i right.
Better*ln to dwell in a corner of a housetop, Than*ld in a house shared with a contentious woman.
The*ln soul of the wicked desires evil; His*ld neighbor finds no favor in his eyes.
When*ln the scoffer is punished, the simple is made wise; But*ld when the wise is instructed, he receives knowledge.
The*ln righteous God*i wisely considers the house of the wicked, Overthrowing*ld the wicked for their*i wickedness.
Whoever*ln shuts his ears to the cry of the poor Will*ld also cry himself and not be heard.
A*ln gift in secret pacifies anger, And*ld a bribe behind the back, strong wrath.
It*iln is*i a joy for the just to do justice, But*ld destruction will*i come*i to the workers of iniquity.
A*ln man who wanders from the way of understanding Will*ld rest in the assembly of the dead.
He*ln who loves pleasure will*i be*i a poor man; He*ld who loves wine and oil will not be rich.
The*ln wicked shall*i be*i a ransom for the righteous, And*ld the unfaithful for the upright.
Better*ln to dwell in the wilderness, Than*ld with a contentious and angry woman.
There*iln is*i desirable treasure, And*ld oil in the dwelling of the wise, But*ld a foolish man squanders it.
He*ln who follows righteousness and mercy Finds*ld life, righteousness, and honor.
A*ln wise man*i scales the city of the mighty, And*ld brings down the trusted stronghold.
Whoever*ln guards his mouth and tongue Keeps*ld his soul from troubles.
A*ln proud and*i haughty man—*i “Scoffer” is*i his name; He*ld acts with arrogant pride.
The*ln desire of the lazy man*i kills him, For*ld his hands refuse to labor.
He*ld covets greedily all day long, But*ld the righteous gives and does not spare.
The*ln sacrifice of the wicked is*i an abomination; How*ld much more when*i he brings it with wicked intent!
A*ln false witness shall perish, But*ld the man who hears him*i will speak endlessly.
A*ln wicked man hardens his face, But*ld as*i for*i the upright, he establishes his way.
There*iln is*i no wisdom or understanding Or*ld counsel against the Lord.*s
The*ln horse is*i prepared for the day of battle, But*ld deliverance is*i of the Lord.*s
